title: A case of osteoarticular melioidosis misdiagnosed as extra-pulmonary tuberculosis from low endemicity region in North-western India.
retrieved_preview:
Melioidosis is caused by a facultative intracellular gram-negative bacterium, Burkholderia pseudomallei.
[1] It is rapidly developing clinical infection particularly in patients with risk factors of diabetes mellitus, hazardous alcohol use, chronic renal disease, chronic pulmonary disease, immunosuppression and malignancy [2]. The most common mode of transmission is direct inoculation from contaminated soil or water through skin abrasions. Inhalation and ingestion are other known modes of transm

title: The Hidden Threat: Polyarticular Septic Arthritis Unmasking Disseminated Melioidosis.
retrieved_preview:
Polyarticular septic arthritis with an atypical course should prompt evaluation for melioidosis, as early recognition and targeted antimicrobial therapy are essential to prevent dissemination and relapse.

Septic arthritis is a common orthopedic emergency which causes significant mortality and morbidity. It is noted to have a case fatality rate of 5–15% and irreversible joint damage in 25–50% patients afflicted [1]. Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species are the most common causative organism;

title: A Rare Case of Melioidosis Breast Abscess in Far North Queensland.
retrieved_preview: Melioidosis is a rare tropical infection caused by the Gram-negative bacterial organism Burkholderia pseudomallei, which often resides in soil, water, and plants [1,2]. During January 1998-December 2019, the annual incidence of melioidosis in Far North Queensland, Queensland, Australia, more than doubled [3].
